children.subject: Take the Intro to Algorithmic Thinking DeCal that is being offered for the first time this semester!!
<md>I don't have any other advices other than just practicing a lots.</md>

<md>I aced every single interview, and here are my recommended 6 steps.

Step 0: Do not jump into solving the problem right away.
Step 1: Repeat the question in a way that you understand. Write out 2 or 3 example input, output.
Step 2: Ask questions about the problem like "Is it ok to assume xyz... ?", "What does abc mean... ?", "Are there any constraints on the input ?".
Step 3: Explain some easy / brute force approaches to the problem, then write down some test cases, and at least 2 edge/corner/boundary cases.
Step 4: Decide the data structure and discuss with the interviewer.
Step 5: Code. While you are coding, tell them what you're doing.
Step 6: Debug. Walk through the test cases again as well as the code. </md>

<md>I passed every CS interview I had.

It is helpful to also think out loud while writing your solution to the problem so that the interviewer knows what steps you're taking and can follow your thought process. It's a good idea to confirm the criterion for correctness before writing your solution because sometimes there are ambiguities that aren't in the problem statement. If you can state your solution as an implementation or variation of a common algorithm, such as BFS, then that's helpful.

For design questions, it's a good idea to walk through an example of input/output behavior, like how the input would affect the output. If you're asked to debug something about a system, start listing off problems that you might experience with the given system. In general, it's helpful to say out loud some of the important considerations in designing your system.

I cannot comment on the behavioral portion too much as I don't have much experience with it (only had 1 behavioral interview which I passed), but in general don't be overly awkward and speak carefully (i.e. think thoroughly before you speak)</md>

history.content: Not prep advice but practical advice during the interview. Like what are some do’s and don’ts.
history.subject: Anyone have advice for coding interviews
